00023 /* The ring buffer implementation gleaned from the wiring_serial library by David A. Mellis. */

00026 #include "planner.h"

00031 
00032 #define SOME_LARGE_VALUE 1.0E+38 // Used by rapids and acceleration maximization calculations. Just needs
00033                                  // to be larger than any feasible (mm/min)^2 or mm/sec^2 value.
00034 
00035 static plan_block_t block_buffer[BLOCK_BUFFER_SIZE];  // A ring buffer for motion instructions
00036 static uint8_t block_buffer_tail;     // Index of the block to process now
00037 static uint8_t block_buffer_head;     // Index of the next block to be pushed
00038 static uint8_t next_buffer_head;      // Index of the next buffer head
00039 static uint8_t block_buffer_planned;  // Index of the optimally planned block
00040 
00041 // Define planner variables
00042 typedef struct {
00043   int32_t position[N_AXIS];          // The planner position of the tool in absolute steps. Kept separate
00044                                      // from g-code position for movements requiring multiple line motions,
00045                                      // i.e. arcs, canned cycles, and backlash compensation.
00046   float previous_unit_vec[N_AXIS];   // Unit vector of previous path line segment
00047   float previous_nominal_speed_sqr;  // Nominal speed of previous path line segment
00048 } planner_t;
00049 static planner_t pl;
00050 
00051 
00052 // Returns the index of the next block in the ring buffer. Also called by stepper segment buffer.
00053 uint8_t plan_next_block_index(uint8_t block_index) 
00054 {
00055   block_index++;
00056   if (block_index == BLOCK_BUFFER_SIZE) { block_index = 0; }
00057   return(block_index);
00058 }
00059 
00060 
00061 // Returns the index of the previous block in the ring buffer
00062 static uint8_t plan_prev_block_index(uint8_t block_index) 
00063 {
00064   if (block_index == 0) { block_index = BLOCK_BUFFER_SIZE; }
00065   block_index--;
00066   return(block_index);
00067 }
00068 
00069 
00070 /*                            PLANNER SPEED DEFINITION                                              
00071                                      +--------+   <- current->nominal_speed
00072                                     /          \                                
00073          current->entry_speed ->   +            \                               
00074                                    |             + <- next->entry_speed (aka exit speed)
00075                                    +-------------+                              
00076                                        time -->                      
00077                                                   
00078   Recalculates the motion plan according to the following basic guidelines:
00079   
00080     1. Go over every feasible block sequentially in reverse order and calculate the junction speeds
00081         (i.e. current->entry_speed) such that:
00082       a. No junction speed exceeds the pre-computed maximum junction speed limit or nominal speeds of 
00083          neighboring blocks.
00084       b. A block entry speed cannot exceed one reverse-computed from its exit speed (next->entry_speed)
00085          with a maximum allowable deceleration over the block travel distance.
00086       c. The last (or newest appended) block is planned from a complete stop (an exit speed of zero).
00087     2. Go over every block in chronological (forward) order and dial down junction speed values if 
00088       a. The exit speed exceeds the one forward-computed from its entry speed with the maximum allowable
00089          acceleration over the block travel distance.
00090   
00091   When these stages are complete, the planner will have maximized the velocity profiles throughout the all
00092   of the planner blocks, where every block is operating at its maximum allowable acceleration limits. In 
00093   other words, for all of the blocks in the planner, the plan is optimal and no further speed improvements
00094   are possible. If a new block is added to the buffer, the plan is recomputed according to the said 
00095   guidelines for a new optimal plan.
00096   
00097   To increase computational efficiency of these guidelines, a set of planner block pointers have been
00098   created to indicate stop-compute points for when the planner guidelines cannot logically make any further
00099   changes or improvements to the plan when in normal operation and new blocks are streamed and added to the
00100   planner buffer. For example, if a subset of sequential blocks in the planner have been planned and are 
00101   bracketed by junction velocities at their maximums (or by the first planner block as well), no new block
00102   added to the planner buffer will alter the velocity profiles within them. So we no longer have to compute
00103   them. Or, if a set of sequential blocks from the first block in the planner (or a optimal stop-compute
00104   point) are all accelerating, they are all optimal and can not be altered by a new block added to the
00105   planner buffer, as this will only further increase the plan speed to chronological blocks until a maximum
00106   junction velocity is reached. However, if the operational conditions of the plan changes from infrequently
00107   used feed holds or feedrate overrides, the stop-compute pointers will be reset and the entire plan is  
00108   recomputed as stated in the general guidelines.
00109   
00110   Planner buffer index mapping:
00111   - block_buffer_tail: Points to the beginning of the planner buffer. First to be executed or being executed. 
00112   - block_buffer_head: Points to the buffer block after the last block in the buffer. Used to indicate whether
00113       the buffer is full or empty. As described for standard ring buffers, this block is always empty.
00114   - next_buffer_head: Points to next planner buffer block after the buffer head block. When equal to the 
00115       buffer tail, this indicates the buffer is full.
00116   - block_buffer_planned: Points to the first buffer block after the last optimally planned block for normal
00117       streaming operating conditions. Use for planning optimizations by avoiding recomputing parts of the 
00118       planner buffer that don't change with the addition of a new block, as describe above. In addition, 
00119       this block can never be less than block_buffer_tail and will always be pushed forward and maintain 
00120       this requirement when encountered by the plan_discard_current_block() routine during a cycle.
00121   
00122   NOTE: Since the planner only computes on what's in the planner buffer, some motions with lots of short 
00123   line segments, like G2/3 arcs or complex curves, may seem to move slow. This is because there simply isn't
00124   enough combined distance traveled in the entire buffer to accelerate up to the nominal speed and then 
00125   decelerate to a complete stop at the end of the buffer, as stated by the guidelines. If this happens and
00126   becomes an annoyance, there are a few simple solutions: (1) Maximize the machine acceleration. The planner
00127   will be able to compute higher velocity profiles within the same combined distance. (2) Maximize line 
00128   motion(s) distance per block to a desired tolerance. The more combined distance the planner has to use,
00129   the faster it can go. (3) Maximize the planner buffer size. This also will increase the combined distance
00130   for the planner to compute over. It also increases the number of computations the planner has to perform
00131   to compute an optimal plan, so select carefully. The Arduino 328p memory is already maxed out, but future
00132   ARM versions should have enough memory and speed for look-ahead blocks numbering up to a hundred or more.
00133 
00134 */
00135 static void planner_recalculate() 
00136 {   
00137   // Initialize block index to the last block in the planner buffer.
00138   uint8_t block_index = plan_prev_block_index(block_buffer_head);
00139         
00140   // Bail. Can't do anything with one only one plan-able block.
00141   if (block_index == block_buffer_planned) { return; }
00142       
00143   // Reverse Pass: Coarsely maximize all possible deceleration curves back-planning from the last
00144   // block in buffer. Cease planning when the last optimal planned or tail pointer is reached.
00145   // NOTE: Forward pass will later refine and correct the reverse pass to create an optimal plan.
00146   float entry_speed_sqr;
00147   plan_block_t *next;
00148   plan_block_t *current = &block_buffer[block_index];
00149 
00150   // Calculate maximum entry speed for last block in buffer, where the exit speed is always zero.
00151   current->entry_speed_sqr = min( current->max_entry_speed_sqr, 2*current->acceleration*current->millimeters);
00152   
00153   block_index = plan_prev_block_index(block_index);
00154   if (block_index == block_buffer_planned) { // Only two plannable blocks in buffer. Reverse pass complete.
00155     // Check if the first block is the tail. If so, notify stepper to update its current parameters.
00156     if (block_index == block_buffer_tail) { st_update_plan_block_parameters(); }
00157   } else { // Three or more plan-able blocks
00158     while (block_index != block_buffer_planned) { 
00159       next = current;
00160       current = &block_buffer[block_index];
00161       block_index = plan_prev_block_index(block_index);
00162 
00163       // Check if next block is the tail block(=planned block). If so, update current stepper parameters.
00164       if (block_index == block_buffer_tail) { st_update_plan_block_parameters(); } 
00165 
00166       // Compute maximum entry speed decelerating over the current block from its exit speed.
00167       if (current->entry_speed_sqr != current->max_entry_speed_sqr) {
00168         entry_speed_sqr = next->entry_speed_sqr + 2*current->acceleration*current->millimeters;
00169         if (entry_speed_sqr < current->max_entry_speed_sqr) {
00170           current->entry_speed_sqr = entry_speed_sqr;
00171         } else {
00172           current->entry_speed_sqr = current->max_entry_speed_sqr;
00173         }
00174       }
00175     }
00176   }    
00177 
00178   // Forward Pass: Forward plan the acceleration curve from the planned pointer onward.
00179   // Also scans for optimal plan breakpoints and appropriately updates the planned pointer.
00180   next = &block_buffer[block_buffer_planned]; // Begin at buffer planned pointer
00181   block_index = plan_next_block_index(block_buffer_planned); 
00182   while (block_index != block_buffer_head) {
00183     current = next;
00184     next = &block_buffer[block_index];
00185     
00186     // Any acceleration detected in the forward pass automatically moves the optimal planned
00187     // pointer forward, since everything before this is all optimal. In other words, nothing
00188     // can improve the plan from the buffer tail to the planned pointer by logic.
00189     if (current->entry_speed_sqr < next->entry_speed_sqr) {
00190       entry_speed_sqr = current->entry_speed_sqr + 2*current->acceleration*current->millimeters;
00191       // If true, current block is full-acceleration and we can move the planned pointer forward.
00192       if (entry_speed_sqr < next->entry_speed_sqr) {
00193         next->entry_speed_sqr = entry_speed_sqr; // Always <= max_entry_speed_sqr. Backward pass sets this.
00194         block_buffer_planned = block_index; // Set optimal plan pointer.
00195       }
00196     }
00197     
00198     // Any block set at its maximum entry speed also creates an optimal plan up to this
00199     // point in the buffer. When the plan is bracketed by either the beginning of the
00200     // buffer and a maximum entry speed or two maximum entry speeds, every block in between
00201     // cannot logically be further improved. Hence, we don't have to recompute them anymore.
00202     if (next->entry_speed_sqr == next->max_entry_speed_sqr) { block_buffer_planned = block_index; }
00203     block_index = plan_next_block_index( block_index );
00204   } 
00205 }
00206 
00207 
00208 void plan_reset() 
00209 {
00210   memset(&pl, 0, sizeof(pl)); // Clear planner struct
00211   block_buffer_tail = 0;
00212   block_buffer_head = 0; // Empty = tail
00213   next_buffer_head = 1; // plan_next_block_index(block_buffer_head)
00214   block_buffer_planned = 0; // = block_buffer_tail;
00215 }
00216 
00217 
00218 void plan_discard_current_block() 
00219 {
00220   if (block_buffer_head != block_buffer_tail) { // Discard non-empty buffer.
00221     uint8_t block_index = plan_next_block_index( block_buffer_tail );
00222     // Push block_buffer_planned pointer, if encountered.
00223     if (block_buffer_tail == block_buffer_planned) { block_buffer_planned = block_index; }
00224     block_buffer_tail = block_index;
00225   }
00226 }
00227 
00228 
00229 plan_block_t *plan_get_current_block() 
00230 {
00231   if (block_buffer_head == block_buffer_tail) { return(NULL); } // Buffer empty  
00232   return(&block_buffer[block_buffer_tail]);
00233 }
00234 
00235 
00236 float plan_get_exec_block_exit_speed()
00237 {
00238   uint8_t block_index = plan_next_block_index(block_buffer_tail);
00239   if (block_index == block_buffer_head) { return( 0.0 ); }
00240   return( sqrt( block_buffer[block_index].entry_speed_sqr ) ); 
00241 }
00242 
00243 
00244 // Returns the availability status of the block ring buffer. True, if full.
00245 uint8_t plan_check_full_buffer()
00246 {
00247   if (block_buffer_tail == next_buffer_head) { return(true); }
00248   return(false);
00249 }
00250 
00251 
00252 /* Add a new linear movement to the buffer. target[N_AXIS] is the signed, absolute target position
00253    in millimeters. Feed rate specifies the speed of the motion. If feed rate is inverted, the feed
00254    rate is taken to mean "frequency" and would complete the operation in 1/feed_rate minutes.
00255    All position data passed to the planner must be in terms of machine position to keep the planner 
00256    independent of any coordinate system changes and offsets, which are handled by the g-code parser.
00257    NOTE: Assumes buffer is available. Buffer checks are handled at a higher level by motion_control.
00258    In other words, the buffer head is never equal to the buffer tail.  Also the feed rate input value
00259    is used in three ways: as a normal feed rate if invert_feed_rate is false, as inverse time if
00260    invert_feed_rate is true, or as seek/rapids rate if the feed_rate value is negative (and
00261    invert_feed_rate always false). */
00262 #ifdef USE_LINE_NUMBERS   
00263 void plan_buffer_line(float *target, float feed_rate, uint8_t invert_feed_rate, int32_t line_number) 
00264 #else
00265 void plan_buffer_line(float *target, float feed_rate, uint8_t invert_feed_rate) 
00266 #endif
00267 {
00268   // Prepare and initialize new block
00269   plan_block_t *block = &block_buffer[block_buffer_head];
00270   block->step_event_count = 0;
00271   block->millimeters = 0;
00272   block->direction_bits = 0;
00273   block->acceleration = SOME_LARGE_VALUE; // Scaled down to maximum acceleration later
00274   #ifdef USE_LINE_NUMBERS
00275     block->line_number = line_number;
00276   #endif
00277 
00278   // Compute and store initial move distance data.
00279   // TODO: After this for-loop, we don't touch the stepper algorithm data. Might be a good idea
00280   // to try to keep these types of things completely separate from the planner for portability.
00281   int32_t target_steps[N_AXIS];
00282   float unit_vec[N_AXIS], delta_mm;
00283   uint8_t idx;
00284   for (idx=0; idx<N_AXIS; idx++) {
00285     // Calculate target position in absolute steps. This conversion should be consistent throughout.
00286     target_steps[idx] = lround(target[idx]*settings.steps_per_mm[idx]);
00287   
00288     // Number of steps for each axis and determine max step events
00289     block->steps[idx] = labs(target_steps[idx]-pl.position[idx]);
00290     block->step_event_count = max(block->step_event_count, block->steps[idx]);
00291     
00292     // Compute individual axes distance for move and prep unit vector calculations.
00293     // NOTE: Computes true distance from converted step values.
00294     delta_mm = (target_steps[idx] - pl.position[idx])/settings.steps_per_mm[idx];
00295     unit_vec[idx] = delta_mm; // Store unit vector numerator. Denominator computed later.
00296         
00297     // Set direction bits. Bit enabled always means direction is negative.
00298     if (delta_mm < 0 ) { block->direction_bits |= get_direction_mask(idx); }
00299     
00300     // Incrementally compute total move distance by Euclidean norm. First add square of each term.
00301     block->millimeters += delta_mm*delta_mm;
00302   }
00303   block->millimeters = sqrt(block->millimeters); // Complete millimeters calculation with sqrt()
00304   
00305   // Bail if this is a zero-length block. Highly unlikely to occur.
00306   if (block->step_event_count == 0) { return; } 
00307   
00308   // Adjust feed_rate value to mm/min depending on type of rate input (normal, inverse time, or rapids)
00309   // TODO: Need to distinguish a rapids vs feed move for overrides. Some flag of some sort.
00310   if (feed_rate < 0) { feed_rate = SOME_LARGE_VALUE; } // Scaled down to absolute max/rapids rate later
00311   else if (invert_feed_rate) { feed_rate = block->millimeters/feed_rate; }
00312 
00313   // Calculate the unit vector of the line move and the block maximum feed rate and acceleration scaled 
00314   // down such that no individual axes maximum values are exceeded with respect to the line direction. 
00315   // NOTE: This calculation assumes all axes are orthogonal (Cartesian) and works with ABC-axes,
00316   // if they are also orthogonal/independent. Operates on the absolute value of the unit vector.
00317   float inverse_unit_vec_value;
00318   float inverse_millimeters = 1.0/block->millimeters;  // Inverse millimeters to remove multiple float divides 
00319   float junction_cos_theta = 0;
00320   for (idx=0; idx<N_AXIS; idx++) {
00321     if (unit_vec[idx] != 0) {  // Avoid divide by zero.
00322       unit_vec[idx] *= inverse_millimeters;  // Complete unit vector calculation
00323       inverse_unit_vec_value = fabs(1.0/unit_vec[idx]); // Inverse to remove multiple float divides.
00324 
00325       // Check and limit feed rate against max individual axis velocities and accelerations
00326       feed_rate = min(feed_rate,settings.max_rate[idx]*inverse_unit_vec_value);
00327       block->acceleration = min(block->acceleration,settings.acceleration[idx]*inverse_unit_vec_value);
00328 
00329       // Incrementally compute cosine of angle between previous and current path. Cos(theta) of the junction
00330       // between the current move and the previous move is simply the dot product of the two unit vectors, 
00331       // where prev_unit_vec is negative. Used later to compute maximum junction speed.
00332       junction_cos_theta -= pl.previous_unit_vec[idx] * unit_vec[idx];
00333     }
00334   }
00335   
00336   // TODO: Need to check this method handling zero junction speeds when starting from rest.
00337   if (block_buffer_head == block_buffer_tail) {
00338   
00339     // Initialize block entry speed as zero. Assume it will be starting from rest. Planner will correct this later.
00340     block->entry_speed_sqr = 0.0;
00341     block->max_junction_speed_sqr = 0.0; // Starting from rest. Enforce start from zero velocity.
00342   
00343   } else {
00344     /* 
00345        Compute maximum allowable entry speed at junction by centripetal acceleration approximation.
00346        Let a circle be tangent to both previous and current path line segments, where the junction 
00347        deviation is defined as the distance from the junction to the closest edge of the circle, 
00348        colinear with the circle center. The circular segment joining the two paths represents the 
00349        path of centripetal acceleration. Solve for max velocity based on max acceleration about the
00350        radius of the circle, defined indirectly by junction deviation. This may be also viewed as 
00351        path width or max_jerk in the previous grbl version. This approach does not actually deviate 
00352        from path, but used as a robust way to compute cornering speeds, as it takes into account the
00353        nonlinearities of both the junction angle and junction velocity.
00354 
00355        NOTE: If the junction deviation value is finite, Grbl executes the motions in an exact path 
00356        mode (G61). If the junction deviation value is zero, Grbl will execute the motion in an exact
00357        stop mode (G61.1) manner. In the future, if continuous mode (G64) is desired, the math here
00358        is exactly the same. Instead of motioning all the way to junction point, the machine will
00359        just follow the arc circle defined here. The Arduino doesn't have the CPU cycles to perform
00360        a continuous mode path, but ARM-based microcontrollers most certainly do. 
00361        
00362        NOTE: The max junction speed is a fixed value, since machine acceleration limits cannot be
00363        changed dynamically during operation nor can the line move geometry. This must be kept in
00364        memory in the event of a feedrate override changing the nominal speeds of blocks, which can 
00365        change the overall maximum entry speed conditions of all blocks.
00366     */
00367     // NOTE: Computed without any expensive trig, sin() or acos(), by trig half angle identity of cos(theta).
00368     float sin_theta_d2 = sqrt(0.5*(1.0-junction_cos_theta)); // Trig half angle identity. Always positive.
00369 
00370     // TODO: Technically, the acceleration used in calculation needs to be limited by the minimum of the
00371     // two junctions. However, this shouldn't be a significant problem except in extreme circumstances.
00372     block->max_junction_speed_sqr = max( MINIMUM_JUNCTION_SPEED*MINIMUM_JUNCTION_SPEED,
00373                                  (block->acceleration * settings.junction_deviation * sin_theta_d2)/(1.0-sin_theta_d2) );
00374   }
00375 
00376   // Store block nominal speed
00377   block->nominal_speed_sqr = feed_rate*feed_rate; // (mm/min). Always > 0
00378   
00379   // Compute the junction maximum entry based on the minimum of the junction speed and neighboring nominal speeds.
00380   block->max_entry_speed_sqr = min(block->max_junction_speed_sqr, 
00381                                    min(block->nominal_speed_sqr,pl.previous_nominal_speed_sqr));
00382   
00383   // Update previous path unit_vector and nominal speed (squared)
00384   memcpy(pl.previous_unit_vec, unit_vec, sizeof(unit_vec)); // pl.previous_unit_vec[] = unit_vec[]
00385   pl.previous_nominal_speed_sqr = block->nominal_speed_sqr;
00386     
00387   // Update planner position
00388   memcpy(pl.position, target_steps, sizeof(target_steps)); // pl.position[] = target_steps[]
00389 
00390   // New block is all set. Update buffer head and next buffer head indices.
00391   block_buffer_head = next_buffer_head;  
00392   next_buffer_head = plan_next_block_index(block_buffer_head);
00393   
00394   // Finish up by recalculating the plan with the new block.
00395   planner_recalculate();
00396 }
00397 
00398 
00399 // Reset the planner position vectors. Called by the system abort/initialization routine.
00400 void plan_sync_position()
00401 {
00402   uint8_t idx;
00403   for (idx=0; idx<N_AXIS; idx++) {
00404     pl.position[idx] = sys.position[idx];
00405   }
00406 }

00408 
00409 // Re-initialize buffer plan with a partially completed block, assumed to exist at the buffer tail.
00410 // Called after a steppers have come to a complete stop for a feed hold and the cycle is stopped.
00411 void plan_cycle_reinitialize()
00412 {
00413   // Re-plan from a complete stop. Reset planner entry speeds and buffer planned pointer.
00414   st_update_plan_block_parameters();
00415   block_buffer_planned = block_buffer_tail;
00416   planner_recalculate();  
00417 }
